TheHeroShep 15-Dec-21 03:42 PM
Been reading a whole bunch of responses & will try & summarize at high level + be non biased: Benefits of burning: - Short term price pump almost guaranteed - Team is freed from having to focus on NCR minting ever again and can focus on product, there is no more discussion about how to handle the mint, Karel doesn't have to mint, no resources used for automating the mint, nothing, it's over. (Note: Frooxius said not a distraction for dev team & that it's only Karel's focus https://discord.com/channels/402159838827905024/468504846522384394/920880536979898408) - Keeping price stable at or near mint floor becomes much more reasonable at $10 than at $29 in the near term - Long term holders now hold a greater % of all NCR in circulation than if another $9M were minted as they presumably would not mint more - Removes the price action of people flipping the buyback program / liquidity / weird dynamics around uniswap and mint being out of sync - CEX's like Kucoin likely wont list us if still in ICO (hearsay) Benefits of not burning: - Team gains an additional $150M of funding if the ICO sells out (that I don't see how they'll make otherwise anytime soon) - The defacto price floor after ICO would be higher ($29 compared to $10.27 currently) - Potentially burning makes a big wave that tries to attract new players and they don't actually join because new user onboarding and website haven't been updated yet - Chance NCR drops significantly after pump if burned because the main places to use it (marketplace / job board) haven't been created yet - You continue to reward patreon subscribers for all the months that ICO continues ongoing (this could be a wash, not sure how it would compare with benefit #4) - Some long term holders may feel gipped / like you capitulated to new investors if you burn - Community development fund receives additional NCR from the batches that would otherwise be burned (If you want me to add something to this just dm me or reply to it) (edited)

Zyzyl 15-Dec-21 04:43 PM
Shep outlined things above pretty well. From my perspective there are a few primary potential problems with a burn: - Loss in ETH income for the team that they would otherwise have had from the mint, $150M worth of ETH is not a trivial amount at all. - Earlier exposure, possibly before the platform and community are ready to handle it. - A perception issue from longer-term users. A lot of people have heard (and agreed) with the team on their slower and steadier approach. This will look like short-term appeasement to many in the community and risks upsetting many of the creators who have supported Neos through hard times (not necessarily my view). - Discontent from Patrons who likely wouldn't receive their NCR kickback every month. - Possibly less stability for the currency in the short term if we do see faster price action. Loss of funding is unarguable really, although the team holds a good chunk of NCR from the buybacks now. They could make back a lot of the potential lost ground by strategically selling that. Re: exposure, I suspect this will be an exponential thing either way. Keeping the ICO would probably delay the horde by a few weeks, months at most, so I'm not sure how important that will really end up being. Unfortunately, I think the perception angle is significant. I think there really has been a negative reaction from many of the longer term Neos users who we need to keep around on the platform because the social side of Neos will live or die by the user generated content. On the other hand, faster price action could lead to longer term holders becoming more financially independent faster - thus more able to spend time creating for Neos. Of course, if they've sold already then it wouldn't have that effect.

Zyzyl 15-Dec-21 05:10 PM
I'm still mulling this over. My instinct is actually that we probably do want to end the ICO sooner rather than later (though burning tokens may not be the only approach to doing that). I'm quite skeptical we'll get through the remainder of the ICO using the original mechanism (the value wall we'd need to scale is enormous, 10x higher than the ICO for a similar metaverse project called Decentraland) and it will continue to be a time sink for Karel unless they change the way they handle transactions. Is it a problem if the ICO doesn't complete soonish? Maybe. It's undeniable that we're in a #metaverse hype cycle at the moment, and it's unarguable that Neos has better VR tech than any other blockchain-enabled competitor. We could capitalise on that, higher prices bring more attention & potentially more users. I think the usability complaint is actually slightly overblown, it's a problem for certain demographics, but probably not for crypto people. They're used to dealing with crappy UX in crypto space. Would be a big risk if the community / team can't absorb that amount of attention though. Tbh I've been a bit disappointed by the response from many of the long term users recently, but the existing community has made Neos what it is. It would be an enormous risk to make large changes which could upset them - any major changes would need to be carefully explained. I think there is a bit of a risk of people giving up on NCR if they don't see it as having room to increase in price. Why would you hold a coin which doesn't have much upside potential? Karel has already said that there will be alternative payment mechanisms available on the Neos store. I'm not convinced there will be much incentive to hold NCR long term if the ICO doesn't complete; it puts a pretty brutal ceiling on the price and we're dependent on the Neos team to prop up the token on the downside.

Zyzyl
I'm still mulling this over. My instinct is actually that we probably do want to end the ICO sooner rather than later (though burning tokens may not be the only approach to doing that). I'm quite skeptical we'll get through the remainder of the ICO using the original mechanism (the value wall we'd need to scale is enormous, 10x higher than the ICO for a similar metaverse project called Decentraland) and it will continue to be a time sink for Karel unless they change the way they handle transactions. Is it a problem if the ICO doesn't complete soonish? Maybe. It's undeniable that we're in a #metaverse hype cycle at the moment, and it's unarguable that Neos has better VR tech than any other blockchain-enabled competitor. We could capitalise on that, higher prices bring more attention & potentially more users. I think the usability complaint is actually slightly overblown, it's a problem for certain demographics, but probably not for crypto people. They're used to dealing with crappy UX in crypto space. Would be a big risk if the community / team can't absorb that amount of attention though. Tbh I've been a bit disappointed by the response from many of the long term users recently, but the existing community has made Neos what it is. It would be an enormous risk to make large changes which could upset them - any major changes would need to be carefully explained. I think there is a bit of a risk of people giving up on NCR if they don't see it as having room to increase in price. Why would you hold a coin which doesn't have much upside potential? Karel has already said that there will be alternative payment mechanisms available on the Neos store. I'm not convinced there will be much incentive to hold NCR long term if the ICO doesn't complete; it puts a pretty brutal ceiling on the price and we're dependent on the Neos team to prop up the token on the downside.

Irick 16-Dec-21 01:14 AM
Okay. So. I read over this entire thread @_@. I am by no means an expert, so i'm just going to talk from the heart here: This was the wrong move. The animosity within the community between the regulars and the recent influx of a non-intigrated crypto-culture is absolutely being flared, not to mention pretty much none of us have the expertise to really advise on this. I hate to make the Brexit comparison, but, there you go. From where I stand, breaking from the whitepaper feels like a discounting of the long term vision that I at the very least felt represented just how different Neos was from other projects that incorporate crypto currency into their core models. The recent activity in this sector is baffling, and it's been very hard to engage with segments of the incoming population for me. Decentralized architectures are the only way we can build this thing right, and for that point alone I agree with the choice to base the in game economy on a blockchain based token. I fail to see how burning NCR makes us more robust to network degradation. I fail to see how burning NCR flattens or resists large third party holder market manipulation. I fail to see how this move is consistent with the philosophical core of the project. Because of that, and the lack of time that we've had to integrate the new voices into the existing culture of Neos, I can only in good conscious vote for the vision laid out in the white paper and hope that, given the time to acculturate, we can have a better dialog with the incoming community about the future of the platform both in terms of rewarding new entrants and keeping the spark that ignited our creative instincts. I want this platform to be accessible, and ending the mint seems like it would put up massive technical hurdles for most people to even start partisipating in our economy.

probably better to put my thoughts here than the main chat: I dont feel the burn is a good idea for a couple reasons- mainly in that as stated in the white paper, NCR is supposed to be the token of the Neos economy while providing funding for the team in it's initial sale. It feels like reducing the spead of NCR to more possible users through patreon or other methods is working opposite to that idea. Right now we are talking about at least 1/5 of the NCR that should be in circulation. Burning cements those tokens as a store of wealth rather than any sort of currency since it makes it more difficult for new users to have a chance to get any NCR for marketplace usage. My other reason is that a burn feel like a short term solution to what should be a long term goal. While we were burning through liquidity trying to keep the price above $7, I dont see that any burn will help that other than drive the price high temporarily. People are going to dump if the price jumps fast as they always do and a CEX isn't going to help that. The team gets no benefit monetarily from burning unless they are hoping to get VC afterwards as the market isnt ready (and will be poisioned as mentioned above) and Patreon support will dry up from no NCR rewards. Personally I dont see Neos at risk of failure right now from not kissing the feet of people that want quick cash. The team would be better off catering to its player base AND investors that are in for the long haul rather than those treating it like the next pump and dump coin.

And you can see from the tokenomics that they were designed to reward the early contributors through cheap early pricing and kickbacks every 25th batch. What would be interesting would be to understand how much of the Patreon rewards are being sold over time. I have the feeling that any drive to make this about money is likely to receive significant pushback from the heart of the community, and potentially jeopardising the timeline to complete the roadmap. An equally important topic to address will be the utility of NCR in-game and adjusting the rates required to purchase and do things. Axie started to struggle when the ratio of AXS/SLP shot-up so high that it reduced (early) breeding activity and resulted in high SLP inflation due to more being minted as battle rewards than burned via breeding. In other words, dynamic adjustment as the game develops and the value of NCR changes is important to address. Post-note on teokenomics: regarding the burn, another thing to take into account is timing. BTC is not exactly stable right now and there is a scenario that you execute the burn and then BTC crashes eliminating any short term gains (as well as the scenario of BTC pumping shortly after and boosting the gains). In other words, a gain is not guaranteed. End of ramble...
1

Feynt 16-Dec-21 08:40 AM
Going to be a for me. I believe strongly that decent portion of the patreon supporters are supporting specifically because of the NCR payout. If there's no payout, their incentive to fund the project directly wanes and they'll instead invest specifically in the credits. I'm not sure what that means for support of the Neos team, however if the intention is to use NCR as an ingame currency for the exchange of goods and services, this just becomes a capitalist's wet dream. Everyone who supports the project because they believe in Neos (and is currently getting a kickback for doing so) is stuck with their amount of NCR now, and possibly won't have the means to buy more. Everyone investing in the credits themselves likely has the monetary option to buy big and horde, reducing the actual available currency for goods exchange while artificially inflating its value due to scarcity, then prompting a mass sell which will crash the economy and ruin NCR as a market for creators. Now, granted, an approximate burn of 9M is not the greatest loss in the face of 41M already minted and out there in circulation, however: - Going full trade mode and prompting more people to explore Neos now isn't necessarily a great idea when Neos is still effectively alpha state (i.e. not feature complete) - I echo the worry others have mentioned, having a price bump due to a burn would likely prompt a mass selloff from current credit holders as soon as the value hike begins to plateau, crashing the market value. - A new incentive would need to be offered to patreon backers to replace the NCR value, as currently the NCR received (converted to fiat currency) outweighs the actual cost of the patreon amounts
